subject: Re: [junit] Running time consuming JUnit Tests
msgSnippet: Hello again, I think you misunderstood me.  Let s say that String.length() returns a wrong length when there s a zero char in a String.  So, you original code
messageBody:
Hello again,

I think you misunderstood me. Let's say that String.length() returns a
wrong length when there's a zero char in a String. So, you original code
would have been this:

public void testDomainTest() {
String s = createString(); // Method which potentially returns
// a String with a character of zero value
assertEquals(12, s.length());
}

So, when you encounter the bug, this test fails. After investigating,
you discover that the JDK platform has the bug. So now, you should add a
test like this:

public void testStringLengthHasBug() {
String s = "a\u0000a";
assertEquals("Bug in JDK returns one less char "
+ "per char at zero value", 2, s.length());
}

And you update your domain code to remove or translate the zero char
value.

When you next update your JDK, you run your tests again. Now, the
testStringLengthHasBug() method fails, because the bug was corrected.
So, you can safely remove the foolproof code, and update your domain code
to correct the problem.

I understand that the example is not quite correct, as you would not
normally have something related to the JDK platform, but this simple
example serves to illustrate my point.

Hope that helps !
Francois Beausoleil


On Fri, 06 Dec 2002 10:09:06 -0800, "Vladimir R. Bossicard"
<vbossica@...> said:
> > In my opinion, you should reverse your test. So, instead of failing
> > because the library has bad code, your test now fails if the library has
> > *good* code. Then, you should have another test which tests *your* code
> > and makes sure that you prevent the bug from happening.
>
> The problem I have is that now that all my tests pass with a buggy code,
> how can I trust my tests? What will remind me that my code is broken if
> my failing tests pass?
>
> If I'm the only one on the project, I can keep track of the open issues
> (like upgrading a library) but things get complicated as soon as you
> have some decentralized organization (OSS e.g.)
>
> I think it's important that you have a red flag somewhere, and possibly
> automatic (not a todo list that you may or may not keep up-to-date).
> For JUnit-addons, I wrote a validator that checks for tests that are not
> starting with "test" and gives a notice. I think that I will run this
> automatically in my build and comment-out my test (like "public void
> failing-test"): all my tests now pass but I have an automatic reminder
> that they are in fact broken. The rule will be: all the defined tests
> must pass and no test must be commented-out.
>
> -Vladimir
